title: Aaron Paul: Breaking Bad: El Camino was meant to end with Brock's letter
text:
Jesse’s letter to young Brock was meant to play a bigger role at the end of the movie (Picture: Netflix)

Breaking Bad: El Camino ended on a hopeful note as Jesse Pinkman (Aaron Paul) set off for a new life and new identity with the help of Ed (Robert Forster).

However, in the moments before he left, he gave Ed the one and only thing he wanted to leave behind in Albuquerque, New Mexico – a letter to Brock Cantillo, the young son of Andrea who was left seemingly orphaned after his mother was shot dead back in Breaking Bad.

Viewers never saw what the letter contained – but Aaron Paul has exclusively revealed to Metro.co.uk that it was meant to play a much larger role in the final moments of the film.

Not only does he know what’s in the letter, but he still has it, though will never reveal its contents.

He told us: ‘There was a completely different ending. It ended with the voiceover of Jesse writing the letter to Brock and so, in the initial draft, the audience would’ve heard what was in the letter.

‘That was one thing I fought for. I remember, it was before we started shooting, probably the fourth or fifth time I read through the script and I noticed that the ending was different. I was like “wait…why? Why has this gone?” and I called Vince [Gilligan] and asked “Why did you take out the letter?!”

‘He’s this southern gentleman, just such a great man, such a beautiful sweet accent, he went “I just felt it was kind of a downer reminding people what had happened, and I don’t know, it just felt a little sad”,’ he revealed.

Brock was the only person Jesse said goodbye to (Picture: Netflix)

‘I disagreed with him and I fought until the end of the shoot to at least have me record the voice over,’ Aaron continued. ‘There’s a small scene of him in the little secret cabinet that he was hiding in in the moving truck, where he comes out.

‘There’s a scene in there where he’s writing a letter and you’re not sure who he’s writing it to, but you sort of get a glimpse. Then next time you see that letter is when he hands it to good old Robert Forster.’

‘That was the one thing I took from the set, I took the letter,’ Aaron concluded – but stopped shy of telling us anything about its contents, the spoil sport.

Jesse left his old life behind in the final moments of El Camino (Picture: Netflix)

‘I wish I could tell you, it’s such a beautiful letter, it’s so well thought out,’ he teased.

‘It’s actually the first thing that Vince wrote when he wrote the script, was that letter. The very first thing he wrote, he wrote a letter to Brock from Jesse, which is just… so beautiful.’

Unfortunately, we’ll never know the full content of the letter, as it hit the cutting room floor along with numerous other scenes that will never see the light of day.

‘The original cut of this film was just under three hours. It was two-hours and 57mins? So about a third of it was cut,’ Aaron added.

‘A lot of that was just trimming of scenes, some scenes were able to breathe a little longer, but then there was full-on scenes that were cut either from the script or from the final cut, or from the initial cut. There was stuff that was cut even before we started shooting.’

The fate of Brock remained unknown throughout El Camino, with the death of his mother still recent in the timeline of the series.

But it’s clear that out of everyone that had been caught up in the trouble started by Heisenberg and the blue meth trade he was dragged into, Jesse felt the most guilty about the young boy’s unwitting involvement.
